questions.text: Which one of the following pathological features has a higher risk of developing into invasive breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Atypical hyperplasia has a higher risk of developing into invasive breast carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma

Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on pathological examination of benign breast tissue (American College of Pathologists Consensus Statement):

  • No increased risk
    • Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
    • Apocrine metaplasia
    • Cysts, macro and/or micro
    • Duct ectasia
    • Fibroadenoma
    • Fibrosis
    • Hyperplasia
    • Mastitis (inflammation)
    • Periductal mastitis
    • Squamous metaplasia
  • Slightly increased risk (1-5 - 2times)
    • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid or papillary
    • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core
  • Moderately increased risk (5 times)
    • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular)
  • Insufficient data to assign a risk
    • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
    • Radial scar lesion

questions.text: A  woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancers underwent genetic testing. She is found to have a BRCA1 gene mutation.  Which of the following is she at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Individuals with BRCA1 mutations are likely to develop triple receptor-negative and high-grade breast carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated

questions.text:
Which of the following does not increase the risk of breast carcinoma in women?
  1. Early age of first pregnancy
  2. Positive family history
  3. Breastfeeding
  4. Early menarche and late menopause
  5. Multiparity
questions.solution:
Early age of first pregnancy, breastfeeding, and multiparity are protective factors for carcinoma of the breast. This is due to a reduction in the overall number of ovulatory cycles thereby reducing the duration of estrogen's action on the breast tissues. 

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: The most common location of breast carcinoma is the _______.
questions.solution: The upper outer quadrant of the breast has a greater volume of tissue and is the most common site of breast carcinoma.

questions.text: A woman presented to the clinic with redness and itching over the left breast as shown in the image below.  Histopathology showed large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and histology are suggestive of Paget's disease of the breast. 

Paget’s disease is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple-areolar complex, often with an underlying in-situ or invasive ductal carcinoma. It presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. Paget disease of the breast is often mistaken for eczema. 

  Paget's disease Eczema
Laterality Unilateral Bilateral
Age group Menopausal women Lactating women
Edges Distinct Indistinct
Vesicles Absent Present
Nipple Usually destroyed Usually intact
Lump Usually present No underlying lump 

A nipple biopsy specimen of Paget's disease will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition.

Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Note: Histologically, Paget's disease can be confused with superficial spreading melanoma, particularly if they have incorporated melanin from adjacent epidermis. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.text: Which is the most common variant of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution: Invasive ductal carcinoma (not otherwise specified) is the most common variant of breast carcinoma. It is also known as infiltrating ductal carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding breast carcinoma?

choices.text: Cutaneous oedema in inflammatory carcinoma is the result of blockage of the sub-dermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells
Mucinous carcinomas are usually hormone negative
Calcifications  are frequently associated with ductal carcinoma in situ
Lobular carcinoma in situ is multi centric and bilateral

questions.solution:
Mucinous carcinoma is usually hormone-positive (90%). It is also called colloid carcinoma. It is a low-grade tumor with a good prognosis. It typically presents as a bulky mass in the elderly. 

Option A: Pathologic hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma is a painful, swollen breast, which is warm with cutaneous edema due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells.

Option C: Calcification is usually associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). It is the most common malignancy detected in screening mammograms.

Option D: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is mainly multicentric (sometimes multifocal) and bilateral.

questions.text:
Arrange the following subtypes of breast carcinomas according to the best to worst prognosis?
1) Medullary carcinoma
2) Tubular carcinoma
3) Invasive ductal carcinoma(NOS)
4) Inflammatory carcinoma
5) Invasive lobular carcinoma
questions.solution:
Tubular carcinoma has the best prognosis. Inflammatory carcinoma has the worst prognosis. 

Order of breast carcinomas from best to worst prognosis:

  • Tubular carcinoma (Best prognosis)
  • Adenocystic
  • Cribriform carcinoma
  • Papillary carcinoma
  • Medullary carcinoma
  • Invasive lobular carcinoma
  • Invasive ductal carcinoma (NOS)*
  • Inflammatory carcinoma breast (Worst prognosis)

NOS- Not otherwise specified

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acute mastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present. 

A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema and edema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Treatment includes combined-modality treatment:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumors
  • Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solid encapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in the breast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision.

Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or wide local excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with a mastectomy.

Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady came to the clinic with complaints of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange peel-like appearance, also called as peau d’orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma.

Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin.

Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction.

Cancer-en-cuirasse is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous infiltration of the cancer cells.

Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with a painless lump in the breast. Mammography done showed suspicious microcalcifications. USG-guided core biopsy revealed large cells with cytoplasmic mucoid globules and neighborhood calcifications. There is no invasion into the basement membrane and fibrovascular stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of large cells with cytoplasmic mucoid globules with an intact basement membrane, and neighborhood calcifications are characteristic of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). 

Lobular carcinoma in-situ is usually detected as an incidental finding on evaluation of either a mass lesion or abnormalities on mammography. 

The slide below shows cytoplasmic mucoid globules seen in lobular carcinoma in situ.

Option A: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) can have various histological appearances like solid, comedo, papillary cribriform, etc

Option B: Histology of Paget’s disease of the breast shows the presence of large pale vacuolated cells (Paget cells) in the rete pegs of the epithelium.

Option D: Histology of phyllodes tumor consists of nodules of proliferating stromal cells, that are covered by epithelium. This resembles a leaf and is hence termed as phyllodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breast lumps?
questions.solution:
Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).

LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients with LCIS. 

Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of the primary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancer within the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it).

questions.text: An annual screening mammogram done for a middle-aged woman showed clusters of microcalcifications. Stereotactic trucut biopsy revealed a comedo growth pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of microcalcifications on mammography and comedo pattern on histology is suggestive of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).

Treatment:

  • Breast conservation surgery with radiotherapy or,
  • Simple mastectomy- least loco-regional recurrence
  • No role of chemotherapy
  • If ER, PR +ve- hormonal therapy

Comedo subtype refers to the presence of necrosis. It implies that the tumor cells are growing rapidly and the blood vessel is not able to supply all the malignant cells. On the contrary, non-comedo subtype implies that the tumor is growing slowly and the blood vessel is able to supply all the cells. Therefore, the comedo subtypes are of high-grade DCIS.

questions.text: A woman with BRCA1 gene mutation presented with lumps in both breasts and enlarged axillary lymphadenopathy. She gives a history of breast cancer in her sister. MRI and trucut biopsy done confirmed the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
It is a slow growing tumor
Tamoxifen can be used in the treatment
Has poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma

questions.solution:
Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. 

Medullary carcinoma is a common type of breast cancer associated with BRCA1 gene mutation. Bilateral tumors are common when family history is present. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative (ER/PR/Her-2 negative).

Histopathology consists of:

  • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
  • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation

It has a better prognosis than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.

questions.text: A male patient who presented with a lump in his right breast is diagnosed to have breast carcinoma. Which of the following is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: The prognosis is worse than in females
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type
Tamoxifen is not effective in treatment

questions.solution:
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer seen in men.

Breast cancer in men accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers. The peak incidence is between 60-70 years of age. Majority of the patients present with a hard mass in the breast. Important risk factors are:

  • BRCA2 mutation
  • Radiation exposure
  • Estrogen therapy
  • Testicular feminizing syndrome
  • Klinefelter syndrome

Diagnosis of male breast carcinoma is similar to females which involves a clinical examination, imaging, and tissue biopsy. Grading, treatment, and prognosis are the same as female breast cancer. The majority of male breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive and hence tamoxifen is used in the treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is worried about developing breast cancer. Her mother and sister had developed breast cancer at the age of 30 years and 32 years respectively. She has 2 daughters. After evaluation, she is found to have a BRCA-1 gene mutation. Which of the following methods will you suggest for the maximum risk reduction of developing carcinoma breast in this patient?

choices.text: Close surveillance with MRI every 6 months

questions.solution:
Prophylactic mastectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy will provide maximum risk reduction in this patient with a complete family, a positive gene mutation, and positive family history.

Breast cancer risk reduction techniques:

  1. Lifestyle modification: Low-calorie diet, daily exercise, no smoking, no drinking, etc.
  2. More frequent screening every 6-12 months with mammogram +- MRI
  3. Chemoprevention: Preferred in women >35 years of age in patients who are ER/PR positive. Given for 5-10 years.
    • SERMS (selective estrogen receptor modulators) - Tamoxifen and raloxifene - have adverse effects. If a patient on tamoxifen develops abnormal uterine bleeding, the drug needs to be stopped.
    • Aromatase Inhibitors (AIs): Better tolerated than SERMs have a low risk of cardiovascular and endometrial complications. They are used only in post-menopausal women.
  4. Risk-reduction surgeries: done in patients with gene mutations or patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancers. Provides >90% risk-reduction. Preferred in patients who have completed their family. Best results when done < 40 years of age.
    • Bilateral mastectomy
    • Salpingo-oophorectomy: preferred in patients with BRCA1/2 mutations to prevent the risk of ovarian cancer too.
